data.title: Native iOS camera support
data.description: Does Animator support an iOS native function to incorporate the camera?
data.body:
We do not offer this functionality at the moment. It is something we have planned for the future. 

For now, it's up to a developer to create the app that handles camera access, and the animations created with Animator can integrate super easily with that codebase.

data.title: Importing SVG's
data.description: What if I don't use Sketch / Figma / Illustrator?
data.body:
Animator integrates with a number of design tools, and we plan on growing that list in the future, plus adding our own drawing tools.

In the meantime, what happens if you don't use any of our currently supported design tools? We've got you covered! You can also import SVG files directly.

To do it, follow these steps:

  1. Create a new project from the dashboard


2. Click the [+] button in the library


3. Select the [Import from file] option


4. Select an SVG from your finder/explorer to import it. It will show up in the library under "Designs".


5. Once you've imported your SVG you can drag and drop it into the stage to animate it!

Important to note

All SVG’s are not born equal and depending on how they’re constructed you could run into some issues with them, as they’re the less tested asset path for us at the moment. But that said, if you run into any issues, just let us know (preferably, with the SVG files!) and we’ll get them fixed up for you.

data.title: Integrations
data.description: What design tools can I use to import slices to Animator? How can I embed my animation once it's done?
data.body:
Design tools

You can import your designs from:

  • Sketch

  • Figma

  • Adobe Illustrator

  • SVGs

Read more here.

Cross-platform

Embed your animation using:

  • Vanilla JS

  • HTML + CDN

  • React

  • Vue

  • Angular

  • Lottie (iOS & Android)

Once your animation is ready, you will find instructions on how to embed it in the "Publish" modal.

Read more here.

Other formats

You can also save your animation u in the following formats:

  • GIF

  • MP4

data.title: Setting the origin point on elements
data.description: How can I change the origin point for scaling or rotating an element?
data.body:
If you hold the cmd key, you'll see the crosshairs in the middle of your selection turn into a control handle. 


While continuing to hold cmd, you can drag that control handle to change the origin. 

You can also change this very accurately using the origin (X and Y) property in the timeline. 


Note that origin, like almost every other property, can be animated using keyframes & tweens.

data.title: Drawing tools
data.description: Can I create my designs in Animator?
data.body:
Animator doesn't currently support drawing tools within Animator itself. 

To start a new project, you'll need to import your design slices via Sketch, Figma, or Illustrator. You can also import SVGs directly!

data.title: Importing designs from Figma
data.description: How to bring assets designed in Figma into Animator for animations and interactions, and troubleshooting common issues
data.body:
HOW TO LINK A FIGMA FILE

The first step to bringing your Figma design to life is to connect it. To do so, simply click on the [+] button at the top of the library panel. 

You can also connect it by clicking the [Figma] button under "Library".

Behind the scenes, we convert all your Figma design's groups, frames, slices, components, and elements with the "Mark for Export" option into individual assets that may be independently composed and animated on stage.

To get an asset on stage, just drag and drop it!

Read more about importing assets from Figma here.

DRAGGING AND DROPPING ITEMS ON STAGE

This one's self-explanatory: to get an item from the Library to the Stage, simply drag and drop. The new element will show up on the stage where you drop it, and a new row will show up in the Timeline representing the new element.

CHANGING ASSETS FROM FIGMA

What if you need to make a change to the Figma file? That's fine! We'll take care of bringing your new changes into Animator and onto any assets you've placed on the stage.

To make changes to your Figma-linked assets, just edit your Figma file and click the refresh button in Animator's library to pull the latest changes from your Figma project.

TROUBLESHOOTING

If you're having trouble getting your Figma assets into Animator, check the following:

  • Ensure that Haiku.app is installed in your /Applications folder.

  • Ensure that you've marked your Figma assets for export, or sliced, or grouped them. Read more here.

  • Ensure that you've clicked the refresh button in Animator's Library to pull the latest changes from your Figma project.

data.title: Importing designs from Adobe Illustrator
data.description: How to bring assets designed in Adobe Illustrator into Animator for animations and interactions, and troubleshooting common issues
data.body:
HOW TO LINK AN ILLUSTRATOR FILE

The first step to bringing your Illustrator design to life is to import it. To do so, simply click on the [+] button at the top of the library panel. 

You can also create a brand new file by clicking the [Illustrator] button under "Library".

Behind the scenes, we convert all your Illustrator design's artboards into individual assets that may be independently ungrouped and animated on stage.

To get an asset on stage, just drag and drop it!

DRAGGING AND DROPPING ITEMS ON STAGE

This one's self-explanatory: to get an item from the Library to the Stage, simply drag and drop. The new element will show up on the stage where you drop it, and a new row will show up in the Timeline representing the new element.

CHANGING ASSETS FROM ILLUSTRATOR

What if you need to make a change to the Illustrator file? That's fine! We'll take care of bringing your new changes into Animator and onto any assets you've placed on the stage.

When you import an Illustrator file, we automatically make a copy of that file and start tracking changes behind the scenes with Git. What this means is if you make changes to your original file, they won't show up by default in Animator.

To make changes to your Illustrator-linked assets, double-click the Illustrator file in the library. Illustrator will launch, and when you Save in Illustrator, changes will automatically be tracked in Animator. Even elements already on the stage remain linked and can be updated directly from Illustrator.

TROUBLESHOOTING

If you're having trouble getting your Illustrator assets into Animator, check the following:

  • Ensure that Haiku.app is installed in your /Applications folder.

  • Ensure that Illustrator is also installed in your /Applications folder.

  • Ensure that you've placed your assets inside artboards.

  • Ensure that you've saved your Illustrator file after creating your design assets and placing them inside artboards.

  • Remember you can have different assets within the same artboard, and ungroup them once in Animator.

  • If you imported a pre-existing Illustrator file, note that Animator makes a copy of the Illustrator file that you import.  If you make changes to the original file, Animator will not automatically copy those changes over to the new file.  As a result, after importing a file, we recommend closing the original Illustrator file and opening the copy through Animator by double-clicking it in the Library.

data.title: Preview your animation in a mobile device
data.description: Can I see a preview of my animation in a mobile device?
data.body:
Is there a companion app for Animator?

We haven't yet created a "mirror" app, though one simple option for now would be to load the "share page" on your device (the one you get from publishing), then Publish in Animator > Refresh on your device each time you want to see the change.

Can I preview my animation on a mobile device?

If you're planning to export to Lottie for use on mobile, we recommend installing the Lottie app from the App Store or Play Store. You can use editor.lottiefiles.com to upload your JSON, then it will give you a QR code that you can load with the Lottie iOS/Android app for previewing on your device. 

If you're not planning to use Lottie and are developing a mobile web app instead (e.g. React/Angular/Vue) you can open your publish link directly in your phone; Animator projects aren't "prototypes" per se, since they're production-ready. That is, what you see is what you'll get in the mobile browser.

data.title: Is it possible pass props for a RN component?
data.description: In React Native we use Lottie and it doesn't accept props.
data.body:
Since we rely on Lottie for iOS and Android rendering, it will be the same; you can't pass in props and have Animator respond to them. Not yet, anyways! 

We're working with the Lottie team to bring our integration closer, and part of that will be the ability to run Expressions and Actions, plus manage States, with Animator+Lottie.

data.title: Does Animator support calculations?
data.description: Use calculations in the attributes panel for accurate results.
data.body:
Calculations are already supported! 

You can start any property's value with an = sign (like in Excel), then whatever you enter afterwards is calculated as a line of Javascript. For example, you can type = 2 * Math.PI to enter a precise 360 degree rotation.

Learn more in our docs!

data.title: Is it possible to call an external Javascript function from within Animator?
data.description: E.g. I want to start playing an embedded video when the user clicks on an object.
data.body:
Yes, you can run arbitrary Javascript inside Actions.  

Probably the easiest way to handle this for now would be to expose a function from your host code base (e.g. a React app) on window, then call that function inside Animator (if(window.playVideo){window.playVideo()}).

There's more information on using Actions (i.e. where you'd put that little code snippet) in this blog post:  https://www.haiku.ai/blog/designing-the-real-thing-with-haiku-actions/

data.title: Does Animator support masking?
data.description: Can I create a mask and animate its contents using Animator?
data.body:
You can't create masks inside Animator at this point, but here are a couple workarounds:

Workaround 1

You can simulate a mask by creating a full-stage layer that's the same color as your expected (host codebase, embedding) background, but with a hole punched out. You can then animate elements underneath, executing a mask.   

This doesn't work for every scenario, but sometimes it's good enough. 

Here are an example you can fork and play with
https://share.haiku.ai/u/taylor/HaiGray

Workaround 2

You can create your mask in Sketch and mark the group that contains the mask as exportable, and it should reflect correctly in Animator.


Important note:

Like we expressed in this article, Animator does not support masking. There are a couple workarounds we've found, that are tied directly to the design tool used (in this case Sketch) and how they manage and export their assets, which are later consumed by Animator.

If Figma, or other supported design tools, don't behave the same way, that's not something we have control over.

data.title: Zooming in and out
data.description: How can I zoom in/out of the timeline and the stage?
data.body:
You have a couple of options to Zoom in and out of both the timeline and the stage:

  1. With your keyboard using cmd +  to zoom in and cmd -  to zoom out.

  2. Using your trackpad by pinching to zoom.

  3. Holding cmd  while scrolling with your mouse.

  4. Using the top nav View > Zoom In/Zoom Out 

  5. You can also use cmd + 0 to reset the zoom.


NOTE: To choose whether to zoom into the timeline or the stage, you need to place your mouse cursor on top of the selected area.

data.title: Is it secure to implement an animation on my web app?
data.description: Are you worried about the script loading from an external source?
data.body:
Great question with a satisfying answer: 

The code produced with Animator is an NPM module, so it can be loaded into any JS-based application and bootstrapped using Haiku Core, which is 100% open source: https://github.com/HaikuTeam/core. 

There’s no need to load the contents from an external source. Instructions for using the components you build in Animator as NPM modules are baked into the share page.


And if you want to mirror the components you create on private version control, there’s nothing preventing that—the whole project is backed by a Git repository which can be pushed to any remote.

data.title: How can I see the animation one frame at a time?
data.description: If the Preview mode is too fast, and you want to see it all happen frame by frame keep reading.
data.body: You can see the animation one frame at a time simply by dragging the playhead across the timeline.

data.title: Once my animation is on a web page, how do I make it responsive?
data.description: Can my animation adapt to different screen sizes?
data.body:
Today the solution is  to "handle responsiveness with code."  You can show/hide different animations based on your medium/screen-size, and you can scale individual animations using your own transforms or the built-in sizing: 'stretch'|'cover'|'contain'|'normal' options, which behave the same as in CSS:

  • If you set it to cover  then it will fill its container by clipping outside the boundaries of the container if necessary.  

  • With stretch it will fill by distorting (doesn't respect aspect ratio).

  • Using contain it will fill without going outside the boundaries. It will make sure that nothing gets clipped out of the window, and will shrink contents instead.

You can pass the sizing option when you initialize your Animator.

Here's a CodePen showing the different sizing modes (commented out in the JS snippet) and the docs that show all of the embed options (though the docs show them in a React context, these same options can be passed into the config in vanilla JS as well, as shown in the former CodePen.)

Troubleshooting

If your animation doesn't show when you embed it using sizing :

  • Try applying a fixed height to the container

  • The mounting may be occurring before the style that specifies height is first applied (e.g. if that height is being applied via React/Angular/Vue). Even without Angular/React/Vue, this is classic "jquery" territory ($( document ).ready( ) Essentially, you'll want to mount the Haiku Animator component only after the document is ready, so that Animator Core's initial measurement of its container is correct. You could look into using a listener like DOMContentLoaded, or even try a hacky approach to wait a fixed amount of time before mounting  setTimeout(()=>{//mount component here}, 500)

Will there be another way to do this in the future?

A near-to-medium term roadmap item is "Layouts", which will have responsiveness built in.  

Another piece that's coming soon is the ability to reference screen & container size inside expressions, so you could handle responsiveness by responding to $screen.width or $container.width.

Stay tuned!

data.title: What is Animator for?
data.description: What's the core idea behind Animator? How is it different from other apps?
data.body:
Animator is a motion design app for creating production-ready animations and UI components. 

We're focused on: 

  1. Design expressiveness (e.g. the timeline, plus the ability to respond to user input and live data) and 

  2. Connected workflows with developers. 

We think being able to create live, usable animations and UI components trumps being able to just make pictures of them. We think developer hand off is a huge problem, not a feature. That is what sets us apart from other design tools. Some of them let you prototype using their screen interactions, others are great for making videos or Hollywood special effects, but it’s ultimately still a mockup that can’t be integrated with your codebase— a developer still has to re-create any designers work by hand.


The most fundamental difference between Animator and those tools is that they’re built around the ‘hand off’ paradigm. With those you’re handing off specs, interactive mockups or generated code to a developer who then integrates it with your codebase. Some of those tools even advertise hand off as a feature, but we think it’s actually part of the problem.

With Animator:

  • Everything is production ready, so you don’t waste time creating throwaway prototypes, as a designer you can author the actual animations and UI components that’ll be used by your website or app.

  • It’s always-integrated, so you can iterate on your designs even after they’ve been integrated with a codebase.

The best example of that is here. There’s an animation authored in Animator, embedded in a web app, and iOS & Android emulators, and you can see even changes made in the Sketch source file being pushed all the way through to the embedded animation in the apps. Unlimited iteration, without needing to constantly ‘hand off’ to a developer or, without a developer needing to re-create your work. 


It really comes down to how closely you want to collaborate:  if a designer is comfortable with "this is my silo; I will hand off this video [or export it to Lottie] and the rest is up to the developer" then Animator probably isn't for them.

If a designer is interested in collaborating with the developer to build the animation or UI together, this is what Animator is all about.  Every action in Animator is backed by a line of code.  Every visual change is automatically handled with a git commit.  When the designer pushes publish, they're doing a git push, and their work is published to npm (these are all literal, not figurative).  Importantly, once the designer's work is part of the UI, they can keep on changing it, iterating, experimenting — because it's connected to the developer through code & version control.

That's why Animator doesn't export measurements and styles, it doesn't “generate code” that you can never touch, and it doesn't lock up your motion design inside arcane object files. At Haiku, we like to say that our design format is code. The format happens to be open source. And although it may not feel like it, every time you edit a project in Animator, you're really editing code. But instead of literally typing instructions into a text file, you're doing so by dragging elements, tweaking numbers with your arrow keys, and pressing 'Play' instead of using the command line.

data.title: How to expand the timeline
data.description: Do you need to see more frames in the timeline? Here's how to do it.
data.body:
By dragging the timeline's horizontal-scroll bar to the right, new frames will be available automatically (similar to infinite scrolling in Excel or Google Sheets).

NEW! You can also pinch to zoom with your trackpad, and cmd+scroll with your mouse.

Note: For it to work, your mouse cursor must be on top of the timeline.

data.title: How to download Animator
data.description: Learn how to get the app on your computer if you are new, or if you already have an account.
data.body:
If you're new to Animator, create an account and download Animator here!  You'll get a 14-day free trial.

If you already have an account and need to re-download, you can do so from: https://inkstone.haiku.ai/v0/download/latest

data.title: How to start a new project
data.description: Different ways to create a new project
data.body:
You can create a new project in two ways:

  1. You can click the [+ New Project] button at the top-right of the dashboard (the screen that shows your grid of projects when you launch the app), or on the big [+ New project] button you'll see next to your projects. 

2. You can fork any existing Public project — this will make a new project that's a copy of an existing one.  You can try this out by clicking the [Fork] button at any of the animations on https://share.haiku.ai/.

data.title: EU Data Subject Rights
data.description: Your rights as a user from the European Union
data.body:
Haiku securely stores your personal data to run our services. As a user from the European Union, under General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) you have the right to request for personal data, and also exercise your right to be forgotten.

To exercise these rights, please email support@haikuforteams.com from the email address used to create your account.

data.title: Tutorials and learning resources
data.description: Getting started, video tutorials and other resources
data.body:
Getting started

If you're new to Animator, we recommend starting with this blog post, and accompanying video tutorial.

Learning resources

Find tutorials and learning resources at this page:

https://www.haikuforteams.com/learn/

You can also check:

  • Docs

  • Help

  • Blog

Slack Community

You can join our Slack Community to send feedback, ask for support, share your projects, and exchange tips and tutorials with other fellow animators.

  • https://www.haiku.ai/slack-community/ 

Learn from others

Another great way to learn is to fork components that you like from https://share.haiku.ai/ and see how they were built.

YouTube

  • Videos

  • Tutorials by Taylor Poe, our Design Lead

Tutorials created by our users 

  • Using states and actions in Haiku - Stop and play button interaction

  • Menu overlay transition with Haiku - Timelapse

  • Getting Started with Haiku - Animating a record player

Did you create a tutorial that you'd like to share with our community? Contact us!

data.title: Animator for Windows
data.description: A desktop app for Windows users
data.body:
We have an internal build for Windows, but we haven’t made it publicly available yet. 

We’ll do all closed beta before a full rollout; please join the waitlist if you’d like early access for Windows: https://www.haikuforteams.com/windows-and-linux/

data.title: How to reset your password
data.description: If you can't remember or forgot your password
data.body:
To reset your password, enter the email address you used to register here:

https://account.haikuforteams.com/reset-password

data.title: Importing designs from Sketch
data.description: How to bring assets designed in Sketch into Animator for animations and interactions, and troubleshooting common issues
data.body:
HOW TO LINK A SKETCH FILE

The first step to bringing your Sketch design to life is to import it. To do so, simply click on the [+] button at the top of the library panel. 

You can also create a brand new file by clicking the [Sketch] button under "Library".

Behind the scenes, we convert all your Sketch design's artboards, pages, and slices into individual assets that may be independently composed and animated on stage.

To get an asset on stage, just drag and drop it!

DRAGGING AND DROPPING ITEMS ON STAGE

This one's self-explanatory: to get an item from the Library to the Stage, simply drag and drop. The new element will show up on the stage where you drop it, and a new row will show up in the Timeline representing the new element.

CHANGING ASSETS FROM SKETCH

What if you need to make a change to the Sketch file? That's fine! We'll take care of bringing your new changes into Animator and onto any assets you've placed on the stage.

When you import a Sketch file, we automatically make a copy of that file and start tracking changes behind the scenes with Git. What this means is if you make changes to your original file, they won't show up by default in Animator.

To make changes to your Sketch-linked assets, double-click the Sketch file in the library. Sketch will launch, and when you Save in Sketch, changes will automatically be tracked in Animator. Even elements already on the stage remain linked and can be updated directly from Sketch.

TROUBLESHOOTING

If you're having trouble getting your Sketch assets into Animator, check the following:

  • Ensure that Haiku.app is installed in your /Applications folder.

  • Ensure that Sketch is also installed in your /Applications folder.

  • Ensure that you've marked your Sketch assets for export, OR sliced them.

  • Ensure that you've saved your Sketch file after slicing/marking for export.

  • If you imported a pre-existing Sketch file, note that Animator makes a copy of the Sketch file that you import.  If you make changes to the original file, Animator will not automatically copy those changes over to the new file.  As a result, after importing a file, we recommend closing the original Sketch file and opening the copy through Animator by double-clicking it in the Library.
